authorsByline: Kevin Cortez, Tim Kohut, Amber Joglar
title: These Fog Machines Instantly Transform Any Party. Here’s Why They’re a Halloween Must.
description: Fully lean into the Halloween spirit! These machines offer cool effects and light shows for a mystical atmosphere—on a budget.
content:
Fog machines are an underrated and, frankly, underutilized device when it comes to Halloween hijinks. An intelligently placed fog machine can serve as the finishing touch to your otherwise perfectly executed holiday display—one could even argue it can tie the entire haunted house together.

Nonetheless, it’s a pretty niche subset of decor to really become an expert in. There’s a lot of trial and error involved, and in a pretty oversaturated market, there are arguably too many devices to choose from. Whether you’re looking to accentuate your favorite Halloween animatronics or perfectly light up your front yard for trick-or-treaters, you should at least consider a budget-friendly machine.

If you’re a musician or frequently host shindigs at your home, you might want to opt for something a little more versatile and hardworking. While most fog machines operate similarly and are typically easy to set up, there is still a wide range of products on the market. They come in various sizes and price points, and while some produce a simple cloud of fog, others offer special effects, such as low-lying fog or LED light shows.

Alas, we found some of the best fog machines on the market for all types of use cases. Whether you’re hosting a Monster Mash or a Disco Date Night, there are plenty of high-end options to choose from. Either way, we’ll point you in the right direction. Let’s go through some of our favorites, along with some tips and tricks (pun intended) on picking the perfect fog machine for Halloween and beyond.

Looking for more Halloween display products and tips? Check out our stories on how to hang Halloween decorations, how to make a DIY candy chute, the best LED strip lights, and the best outdoor net lights.
summary: Fog machines are an underrated and underutilized device for Halloween, providing a visually stunning and effective display. While most are easy to set up, there is a wide range of products available for various uses. For instance, consider a budget-friendly machine for high-profile events like Halloween parties or a party where music is played. The article also provides some tips on how to use these devices.
shortSummary: Fog machines can transform Halloween celebrations into festive events, providing affordable, versatile options, and offering unique effects.

Halloween is a great time to put your DIY skills to use so that you can make and hang your own decorations. From scary lights, to duct-tape cords, these tips will help keep your creepiest props and decorations secure through the scary season (and provide a fun thrill for your trick-or-treaters).
Want more best-in-class DIY tips? Join our squad.
1) Get Some Zip Ties
If you're hanging many strings of bright orange lights, then invest a few bucks in a package of zip ties. They come in a variety of sizes and colors. Match the color to whatever you are securing them to so they are more discrete. They can secure your lights to deck railings, porch banisters, fences, or tree branches. They require only seconds to attach, hold the strings tightly in place, and won't damage your surface with nail holes. Plus, they're cheap. To remove the zip ties, use strong scissors or a utility knife.
2) Use All-Purpose Light Clips
Want to hang pumpkin-colored lights from your gutters? You'll want a few of these all-purpose clips. They're inexpensive (about $7 for a 100-pack) and they look a heck of a lot better than clothespins. If you don't have gutters, don't worry—the all-purpose clips also attach to shingles.
3) Buy Duct Tape Cords
Ideally, you want to keep extension and power cords off sidewalks, hallways, or anywhere people walk. But sometimes it's unavoidable. If you must, use duct tape to secure your cords to the surface; it'll reduce the chances of people tripping since they won't be able to hook their toes under the cords.
4) Invest in a Light-Hanging Pole
Before you hang strings of lights in those trees in your front yard, buy a light-hanging pole. It eliminates the need for a ladder, and you can still get the lights onto the highest branches. This is a convenient and safe way to hang lights that won't put you at risk of falling.
5) Rely on a Timer
You don't want to sit up in bed at 2 a.m. in the morning and realize you forgot to unplug your Halloween lights. Save yourself the chilly trip outside in your jammies by putting your lights on an outdoor timer, which will allow you to deactivate the display at preset times. Basic timers start at about $10; you can spend more on a fancy one with a digital display. Photoelectric timers are ideal as they come on when the sun sets so you don't have to continually adjust your timer as the season progresses.
6) Leverage Your Outlets
You probably have more than one outside outlet, so don't pull a Clark Griswold and plug all your lights into a single outlet. As a general rule, avoid plugging more than three strings of lights together. Always use outdoor-approved cables and plugs.
7) Support Your Props
With those ghosts, skeletons, witches, and zombies, you'll get the most scream for your buck by hanging them from trestles or awnings and letting them blow in the chilly October breeze. Just be sure to support their extra weight. One smart way to do this is to use fishing line, which is strong, easy to work with, and invisible at night. Test the strength of the fishing line so you know it can support the weight.
8) Make Double-Sided Tape Your Friend
Double-sided tape works great for adhering decorations to windows or your front door. You can secure the edges of your kids' Halloween projects or store-bought spiders or ghosts so that they won't get damaged or torn by the wind.
9) Set Up Some Creepy Siding
You can attach lights or lightweight monsters to vinyl siding using hooks that cost about $7 for a set of three. They eliminate the need to punch holes in the siding with nails, and they don't leave you stuck with the residue left behind by tape. The hooks slide into place under the vinyl and attach to the lip—you don't even need any tools.
10) Remember to Practice Ladder Safety
Before you decorate your home for Halloween, Christmas, or any other occasion, remember to be smart on your ladder.
Step 1: Make sure the ladder is stable on a flat, level surface. If your yard is not flat, balance the ladder by placing long boards under one of the legs (don't use a small object such as a brick, since the leg can easily slip off). Check that the boards are secured and won't slip.
Step 2: Strap the strings of lights to your work belt before getting on the ladder so that your hands will be free for climbing.
Step 3: Avoid using metal ladders around electrical wires to eliminate the chance of a shock. Move the ladder often instead of leaning off it. We know, moving the ladder frequently is a pain, but not as much as the pain you'll feel if you fall off. And remember, it's always a good idea to have a second person to assist you while doing any jobs that require a ladder.

If you want to create a simple light display for your yard that screams "Happy Halloween," then the casual string of orange pumpkin-shaped lights is a good place to start. But if you're looking to knock the socks off of your trick-or-treaters and have the scariest yard on the block, you're in the right place.
🎃 Love DIY projects? Join Pop Mech Pro for more expert-backed tips and tricks.
Using lighting to your advantage is key to creating an eerie ambiance. With different colors and shadowing techniques, you can create a scary space perfect for some solid Halloween thrills. So without further ado, here are five ways to set up Halloween lights in your yard.
1) Create Eerie Shadows
To make shadows loom large and creepy, place lights low to the ground and aim them slightly upward. The angle will produce elongated, deformed shadows when anyone (or anything) passes in front of the light. Even the family dog will cast a frightful shadow. If you want to create more specific shadow effects, paint or partially cover lenses, or position cutouts or other figures in front of the lights.
2) Add Some Creepy Colors
Choose your colors wisely. Black lights are a Halloween classic, and you can have lots of fun with a black light on the front porch, but they tend to be more silly than scary. Dark blue lights are a more effective way to create a mystical scene—moviemakers often use dark blue lights for moonlit nights or dark interior scenes, for example. Hang a dark blue bulb in your porch-light fixture to turn your front porch into a shadowy dungeon, or use dark blue floodlights to bathe your front yard in eerie moonlight, which makes the perfect lighting for a graveyard display.
3) Use Flickering Flames
Fire is a great way to create chilling ambiance. The flickering orange light seems to deepen nearby shadows, and it makes them move and shift (or is that just something hiding in the darkness?) Use a candle inside a classic jack-o'-lantern, which can cast some truly unnerving shadows if carved and positioned properly.
You could also line your walkway with tiki torches, or just station a couple on either side of your porch. Make sure your open flames are positioned safely—away from where people will walk—and will not be a hazard. If you're not sure, you can always use flickering orange lights or electronic candles.
4) Try Scary Strobe Lights
Resist the temptation to overuse strobe lights. Not only are they headache-inducing (and potentially dangerous for trick-or-treaters with epilepsy), they may look gimmicky if not executed just right. Instead, to create a sense of confusion or to suggest motion in a display, try flickering light, or a light that flashes at more random, slower intervals.
5) Don't Forget Fog
Achieve the best and scariest possible Halloween lighting with a fog machine. Flashing or moving lights at various levels can suggest spirits moving around, or something with glowing eyes lurking in the fog.
You can also create some cool effects with track lighting on the ground, where the color will be reflected and spread in the surrounding fog. Use it to create an eerie glow arising from a decorative grave or a trail of blood running from a gory display. Red lights are a good way to hint at blood, and bright green can make your fog look radioactive or poisonous.

The 11 Best Halloween Animatronics to Become the Spookiest House on the Block
Halloween-ify your yard with these creepy characters.
Gear-obsessed editors choose every product we review. We may earn commission if you buy from a link. Why Trust Us?
If you want to take your Halloween decorating to the next level, your best bet is to invest in a few animatronics to throw into the mix. Anything that moves, lights up, speaks—or all three—is bound to impress, plus it adds some low-key, haunted house vibes to your neighborhood for some family-friendly entertainment.
A good Halloween animatronic has fluid movement that’s designed for a scare instead of a sloppy, obviously fake style. Many of the best options are motion-activated to provide a spook just as someone walks by.
Whether you’re planning to go all out and transform your front yard into a (tasteful) mini theme park or you want to decorate the porch for trick-or-treaters, read on for our top picks for the best Halloween animatronics on the market.
Need more Halloween décor for your home? Check out our picks for the best fog machines and pumpkin carving kits.
The Best Halloween Animatronics
- Best Overall: Haunted Hill Farm Life-Size Animatronic Reaper
- Best Phantom: Seasonal Visions Wailing Phantom
- Best Scarecrow: Sheerlund Creepy Scarecrow
- Best Zombie: Haunted Hill Farm Life-Size Animatronic Zombie Maid
- Best Doll: Best Choice Products Roaming Doll
What to Consider
Budget
No matter what your budget, you’ll need a game plan for how to design your Halloween decorations. Sure, you can spend all your cash on one giant animatronic zombie for the front yard—which is bound to attract a certain sort of attention—but if you want to fully outfit your yard, front hall, porch, or basement, the best way to do so is by creating multiple focal points at different heights to draw the eye.
For example, you’ll want a mix of tall and ground-level freestanding animatronics, plus hanging ones to complete the look. If you need practical tips to get the job done, here’s our deep dive on installing Halloween decorations.
As a general rule, the more sophisticated the animatronic, the higher the price tag—some cost $300 or more. That said, there are plenty of low- and mid-range options available at multiple price points, starting at roughly $25, with several that fall into the $50 to $75 category and a few hovering around $100.
Weather Resistance
The majority of the Halloween animatronics in our story are appropriate for indoor and outdoor use, but note that none are truly waterproof. As such, we recommend keeping them under cover on a porch or beneath an overhang, for example, especially when inclement weather is on the way.
Power Source
Consider whether the animatronics you buy are battery-operated or have plug-in adapters that will work with your setup. This is especially key if you plan on scattering them out in your front lawn or away from nearby power outlets. However, what plug-in options lack in portability, they make up for in reliable power and frights every single night.
Battery operated choices typically won’t last the full season on one battery pack—you might need new batteries if one of your animatronics starts drooping a bit.
How We Selected
We recommend classic Halloween characters—the zombie, the witch, the creepy clown, and the vampire—as well as a few lesser-known (but no less creepy) choices. We made our final choices based on the design, movement, and potential for frights. At the same time, we researched customer reviews to ensure these monsters pass more than the eye test.

These inexpensive sets add brightness—or a rainbow of multicolored hues—to your most lived-in spaces.

From gamers to DIYer looking to brighten up a walk-in closet, LED strip lights are an inexpensive, easy way to liven up—or generally improve—spaces where you spend a lot of time. There are smart options that dim and are ideal for laid-back living rooms, waterproof sets for decks, patios, and pools, and ones with tricked-out features, like colors that change to the beat of music (hello, summer 2021 rooftop dance parties). Whatever your purpose or intention, installing them is the kind of project you can bang out in a weekend, so read on for our top recommendations.
Best LED Strip Lights

What to Consider
There are countless ways to get creative with LED strip lights, but the first thing to consider is an easy one: if you’re planning to use them outdoors—for a deck, patio, or around a pool—make sure to buy a set that’s waterproof, with an IP-67 rating. Related, finding the right set of LED strip lights for you largely depends on where it's going. If you’re a gamer, want to jazz up your car’s interior, or throw a disco dance party, there are sets geared toward those purposes. There are also LED growing light sets for greenhouses and options for lighting up your general living space.
Sets are typically sold in reels, installed with double tape or adhesive backings and clips, and are generally battery powered or corded. On a more granular level, you’ll want to look out for the number of bulbs per strip and the brightness level, expressed in kelvin, which is abbreviated with a “K.” Finally, light sets are often dimmable and controlled via remote or via Bluetooth with an app.

The 8 Best Christmas Net Lights for Easy Holiday Decorating
Avoid the tangled collection of single-strand Christmas lights and opt for these net lights instead.
Gear-obsessed editors choose every product we review. We may earn commission if you buy from a link. Why Trust Us?
Stringing Christmas lights on your holiday tree can be a fun family activity to get you into the spirit of the holidays, but decorating outdoors can be a whole other beast.
Luckily, someone was clever enough to invent Christmas net lights, which are designed in a grid or mesh pattern that makes them ideal for blanketing over bushes, hedges, fences, and trees. Traditional string lights usually have to be individually wrapped or woven between objects, but net lights can be quickly distributed over a surface. That way, it’s easier to get a more uniform look with minimal effort.
Net lights can vary in features, power sources, and how resistant they are to the elements. To help you in your search, we’ve created a lineup of our top picks, along with expert advice to make your holiday decorating a breeze this year.
The Best Christmas Net Lights
- Best Overall: Waterglide Outdoor Christmas Net Lights
- Best for Balconies: Dingfu Hanging Christmas Net Lights
- Best Battery Powered: EaseSolies 100 Christmas Net Lights (2-Pack)
- Best for Small Bushes: Hishiny 100 Christmas Net Lights
- Best for Larger Bushes: Vicila Christmas Net Mesh Lights
What to Consider
Dimensions
Since the hope with net lights is to eliminate the need for multiple sets of string lights and save on time, start with the dimensions. Net grids are either square or diamond-shaped, and can vary in size. Some might only offer enough surface coverage to light a bush or two, while others can cover an entire part of your lawn. Although it may not be exact, it’s essential to find a set that’s as close as possible to the dimensions of the area you plan to decorate.
Power Source
As for power source, there are plug-in, solar, and battery options available. Battery-powered net lights could save you some money on your electric bill, but might not last as long, especially if you’re planning to run them for several hours throughout the day. Plug-ins offer easy setup and accessibility, and some of our lights on this list can even be controlled directly from the power source for even more convenience. Solar-powered net lights don't require any electricity to run, but they may not be as vibrant as lights that have constant access to power.
Bulb Type
There are two main types of light bulbs that you see in Christmas lights: incandescent and LED. Incandescent lights offer that warm, cozy glow typically associated with holiday decor, while LEDs have a more blue-white tone.
LEDs get some gripe because of the cool tone, but they are more energy-efficient and can last longer than incandescents. Based on our research on top contenders and in-house experience with LED Christmas lights, the majority of our recommendations on this list are made with LEDs.
IP Rating
An IP rating determines how well a piece of equipment can resist water, dust, and weather damage. All outdoor lights usually fall between IP44 and IP65, with IP65 being the most ideal rating because it means the set is completely water- and dust-proof. If you live in an area that only experiences moderate weather, a mid-range IP rating protects your devices. But if you experience a lot of winter weather, like rain, snow, and sleet, then opt for a set of net lights with a higher IP rating.
End-to-End Connection
Sets with end-to-end wire connection are ideal for covering more surface area. This type of connectivity is crucial for decorating large hedges or trees without power strips. Almost all of the Christmas net light we write about offer end-to-end connection.
How We Selected
We first reviewed our guides to the best Christmas lights and the best solar powered Christmas lights to determine what criteria would be useful to assess net lights, like IP rating and bulb type. Our selection includes lights in a range of sizes to suit small and large installation projects, as well as the best plug-in, solar-powered, and battery-operated sets. We surveyed the market, and called upon our own hands-on experience to find the best options based on color variety, features, and accessibility. We’ve settled on the following list of the best Christmas net lights that cover a range of dimensions, budgets, and aesthetics.

- An Ohio man has come up with a creative way to celebrate Halloween with trick-or-treaters in the age of COVID-19: a DIY candy chute.
- In 2020, Andrew Beattie repurposed an old shipping tube to create a candy chute that will keep him at least six feet away from the trick-or-treaters who visit his home on Halloween.
- Beattie also recommends wearing gloves and handing out candy from newly opened packages to minimize contact and lower the risk of infection.
Andrew Beattie didn’t let COVID-19 crush his holiday spirit last year. When he considered the problem facing many festive homeowners—how to safely deliver candy to trick-or-treaters—the Cincinnati, Ohio resident used his DIY ingenuity to come up with a creative solution: a DIY candy chute. As we approach our third holiday season amid the pandemic, his design still stands the test of time (and safety).
🔨 You love badass builds. So do we. Let’s get our hands dirty together.
Using only a cardboard shipping tube, orange spray paint, black duct tape, and a string of lights, Beattie came up with a super simple, perfectly PopMech way to dole out goodies while adhering to social distancing rules.
While Beattie used the shipping tube for a 6-by-8-foot photo backdrop he ordered from Amazon to make his chute, you can find similar-sized tubes practically anywhere shipping materials are sold, and even “from carpet and material stores—sometimes for free,” he tells Popular Mechanics.
From there, Beattie made a sign that hangs at the end of the chute telling trick-or-treaters to “place buckets here,” so they know exactly where their treats will come from. He says this also helps everyone stay healthy, since it’s a “touch-free experience.”
If you can’t grab new gear, just raid your garage. “Use what you already have when possible,” Beattie suggests. “Reusing what would otherwise be thrown away is good for the environment and your wallet, so it’s a win-win.”
🎃 Make Your Own DIY Candy Chute
Want to make your own candy chute? Follow these simple instructions:
- Purchase or find used shipping tube.
- Spray paint the shipping tube orange (or another festive color).
- Attach the painted shipping tube to your banister with duct tape.
- String rope lights around the banister and tube.
- Let the good times (and candy) roll!
To further protect the trick-or-treaters in his neighborhood, Beattie will wear a face mask and gloves, and will be handing out candy “directly into the chute from a newly opened bag,” he says.
The best part: You can continue to bust out the candy chute for future Halloweens, even once the pandemic subsides.
“This is something that can be stashed away easily and reused year after year,” Beattie says. “Even when the pandemic has passed, folks with mobility issues will appreciate not having to navigate steps to get close enough to you, as will those who are immunocompromised.”
Don’t forget to tag us if you make your own chute!
